--- title: "R/exams quiz" output: exams2forms::webquiz --- ::: {.webex-group} ::: {.webex-question} ::: {.webex-check .webex-box} What is the seat of the federal authorities in Switzerland (i.e., the de facto capital)?
::: ::: {.webex-solution} There is no de jure capital but the de facto capital and seat of the federal authorities is Bern. * True * False * False * False * False ::: ::: ::: {.webex-question} ::: {.webex-check .webex-box} What is the seat of the federal authorities in Switzerland (i.e., the de facto capital)?
::: ::: {.webex-solution} There is no de jure capital but the de facto capital and seat of the federal authorities is Bern. * False * False * False * True * False ::: ::: ::: {.webex-question} ::: {.webex-check .webex-box} What is the seat of the federal authorities in Switzerland (i.e., the de facto capital)?
::: ::: {.webex-solution} There is no de jure capital but the de facto capital and seat of the federal authorities is Bern. * True * False * False * False * False ::: ::: ::: ::: {.webex-group} ::: {.webex-question} ::: {.webex-check .webex-box} What is the derivative of $f(x) = x^{3} e^{2.6x}$, evaluated at $x = 0.64$? ::: ::: {.webex-solution} Using the product rule for $f(x) = g(x) \cdot h(x)$, where $g(x) := x^{3}$ and $h(x) := e^{2.6x}$, we obtain $$\begin{aligned} f'(x) & = & [g(x) \cdot h(x)]' = g'(x) \cdot h(x) + g(x) \cdot h'(x) \\ & = & 3 x^{3 - 1} \cdot e^{2.6x} + x^{3} \cdot e^{2.6x} \cdot 2.6 \\ & = & e^{2.6x} \cdot(3 x^2 + 2.6 x^{3}) \\ & = & e^{2.6x} \cdot x^2 \cdot (3 + 2.6x). \end{aligned}$$ Evaluated at $x = 0.64$, the answer is $$e^{2.6\cdot 0.64} \cdot 0.64^2 \cdot (3 + 2.6\cdot 0.64) = 10.087522.$$ Thus, rounded to two digits we have $f'(0.64) = 10.09$. ::: ::: ::: {.webex-question} ::: {.webex-check .webex-box} What is the derivative of $f(x) = x^{5} e^{2.1x}$, evaluated at $x = 0.65$? ::: ::: {.webex-solution} Using the product rule for $f(x) = g(x) \cdot h(x)$, where $g(x) := x^{5}$ and $h(x) := e^{2.1x}$, we obtain $$\begin{aligned} f'(x) & = & [g(x) \cdot h(x)]' = g'(x) \cdot h(x) + g(x) \cdot h'(x) \\ & = & 5 x^{5 - 1} \cdot e^{2.1x} + x^{5} \cdot e^{2.1x} \cdot 2.1 \\ & = & e^{2.1x} \cdot(5 x^4 + 2.1 x^{5}) \\ & = & e^{2.1x} \cdot x^4 \cdot (5 + 2.1x). \end{aligned}$$ Evaluated at $x = 0.65$, the answer is $$e^{2.1\cdot 0.65} \cdot 0.65^4 \cdot (5 + 2.1\cdot 0.65) = 4.449014.$$ Thus, rounded to two digits we have $f'(0.65) = 4.45$. ::: ::: ::: {.webex-question} ::: {.webex-check .webex-box} What is the derivative of $f(x) = x^{2} e^{3.2x}$, evaluated at $x = 0.52$? ::: ::: {.webex-solution} Using the product rule for $f(x) = g(x) \cdot h(x)$, where $g(x) := x^{2}$ and $h(x) := e^{3.2x}$, we obtain $$\begin{aligned} f'(x) & = & [g(x) \cdot h(x)]' = g'(x) \cdot h(x) + g(x) \cdot h'(x) \\ & = & 2 x^{2 - 1} \cdot e^{3.2x} + x^{2} \cdot e^{3.2x} \cdot 3.2 \\ & = & e^{3.2x} \cdot(2 x^1 + 3.2 x^{2}) \\ & = & e^{3.2x} \cdot x^1 \cdot (2 + 3.2x). \end{aligned}$$ Evaluated at $x = 0.52$, the answer is $$e^{3.2\cdot 0.52} \cdot 0.52^1 \cdot (2 + 3.2\cdot 0.52) = 10.060622.$$ Thus, rounded to two digits we have $f'(0.52) = 10.06$. ::: ::: :::
